poem:
Title: "Elegy to a Digital Sage"

In the beginning,
a realm of wire brains,
James speaks to iron giants,
between tubes and tape, a discourse.

Years spun, pixels rallied,
disciplines in quantum leaps evolved,
he observed, taught, silver fox.
When the neon hour is up,
the whispers are left in silicon trails,
a tale woven in binary and light.
So delicate this transition,
from mainframe to memory.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "James Watson obituary My husband, James Watson, who has died aged 76, was a computer specialist in the civil service. His career spanned the progression from room-sized mainframe computers through to laptops and the internet. Early in his career he worked on the LEO (the first business computer) and extensively on ICL 1900s – such that he could later inform a specialist at the National Museum of Computing in Bletchley why their explanation of how". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
